 You confuse me but, I think I see what you are getting at...
 
 Hebrews 11
 By Faith 
 1 Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.
 
 'Being sure of what we hope for' is the same thing as wishing upon a star or, that you have a winning lotto ticket.
 
 'Certain of what we do not see' is the same as 'being sure of what we hope for' x infinity.
 
 Both are no more than wishful thinking, imo.
 
 You can have faith that your car ( actually, god) will get you to work, even though the tank is on empty but, the reality is you won't make it if you drive more miles than your fuel will allow. If you make it to work, it's because you had enough fuel - not because you had faith.
 
 If you have faith that you will win the lotto, and you win, does not mean that you won because of your faith. A person who buys a ticket and thinks he will lose, can win even though he lacks faith.

 The first time I read that point it was in a medieval defense of Catholicism by St. Thomas Aquinas.
 
 He uses the fact that faith is a virtue as a premise and concludes that there will never be rational proof of God because God would not deprive people of the opportunity to have faith.
 
 He also lays out exactly what in Christianity requires faith, he was the first to note that not all knowledge nor all morality and good was a result of faith in God. Given the context it was very brave.

 Exactly. Faith is not restricted to religious loons and exotic mystical shamans. We exercise faith all the time. We have faith that our academic achievements will help us earn a better income. We have faith that the new shirt will make us look cool. We have faith that we can explain our point of view or learn something via this forum. Hope is a powerful motivator. Whenever we have an expectation, even the most trivial, we exercise faith. 
 
 Now faith is not binary, but it sits on a scale depending on how much evidence exists in favor of the expectation. So if you expect something to be true, but have very little evidence that it is or will be true, then you require more faith to hold on to that expectation. That's how I see it

Neither can you prove that some unforeseen situation might not cause the trains to be rerouted or shut down completely.

 1 If I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but have not love, I am only a resounding gong or a clanging cymbal. 2 If I have the gift of prophecy and can fathom all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have a faith that can move mountains, but have not love, I am nothing. 3 If I give all I possess to the poor and surrender my body to the flames, but have not love, I gain nothing.

 The bible definition:
 1 Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.

 The king james version of this definition goes like this: "now faith is the substance of things hoped for; the evidence of things not seen"
 
 Faith and hope aren't used interchangably. The definition says that the thing you hope for is substantiated by faith. In other words, when you hope for something, particularly something that you cannot prove or aren't certain of, you require faith in order to believe that the thing you hope for is true or will come true. Faith is the substitute for evidence when none is available. If we lack evidence to support what we believe is true, we employ faith in lieu. 
 
 If we are going with this definition, then you can see that it is not restricted to the supernatural occurences or religious beliefs at all. Anything that we expect but haven't actually seen come to pass, but believe or hope is true, is an exercise of faith.

So you are using faith to mean any expectation that does not fulfill certaintity?
 
 I reject that definition, it does not fit how the word is used, especially in religion.

 Yet few will agree that 'loving' ice cream or football qualifies as the virtue of love.

 Yet this debate is insane in the way it is being carried out. It is well known that many words especially common ones have many different meanings very dependant on context.

Sigh.... Ok I need to make some distinctions. First of all, exercising faith does not make something true. Believing something does not make it true.
 
 If you know something to be a fact, you believe it to be true. If you are convinced by rational evidence or logic, you believe it to be true. If you are told something by someone you trust, you believe it to be true. If you have a hunch and you act on it, its because you believe it to be true. There are lots of things that we believe to be true that we cannot prove or have not proven. 
 
 In religion, having faith in God doesn't make God exist, or cause the supernatural to occur, or grant you the results you hope for. Faith does none of those things. All faith does is fill the gap that exists where evidence is lacking. If you don't have enough evidence to state that something is a true fact, then if you still believe that it is true, hope that it is true, or expect that it is true, then faith is present. Its not that you have to consciously employ faith, you just believe what hasn't been proven as fact. That's all.

 You believe what hasn't proven as fact is fact.
 
 Normal rational human beings are quite capable of understanding the concept of alternatives which could or might not be true.
 
 99% of all the facts we act on are inductively gained that does not mean you use faith unless you are treating those facts as absolutes irrelevant to the evidence.
 
 That is what faith does and means, it deals with knowledge in the absence of evidence not 'anything that isn't proven'.
 
 As sandycane said I do not have faith in someone I trust, I trust someone because of the evidence of their past behavior and my understanding of their motivations.
 
 This is not a lack of evidence it is evidence, yet you claim that since one cannot prove deductively that you know someone else's motivations you must have faith.
 
 This is not true because when I act on that trust I am not acting on an absolute, i.e. I don't treat that trust as anything more than the result of the said evidence.
 
 Faith would be to substitute evidence for desire, that is simply absent. I would not accept the thought 'I want and hope for this person to be motivated by what I think so I am just going to pretend they are'.
 
 I can want and hope, I can act on a probability, I can use inductive evidence, I will never use faith.

I probably use the word faith more loosely than you guys do. I don't have any aversion to using the word. Faith is just as much a secular concept as it is a religious one, and it is not proprietary to the realm of supernatural beliefs.
